19.-Erreur de droit dans les motifs d'un jugement. -- · L'existence d'une erreur de droit dans les motifs d'un jugement de condamnation n'entraîne pas la nullité de celui-ci s'il n'en est pas résulté une mauvaise application de la loi dans le dispositif du jugement. Lorsque les motifs d'un jugement déclarent à tort que l'art. 1er de la Loi Nº 5 de 1908 sur les délinquants d'habitude n'est pas applicable et que le dispositif punit l'accusé d'après le droit commun, il n'y a pas mauvaise application de la loi dans le dispositif du jugement, puisque l'application de cet article est laissée à la libre appréciation du tribunal. (Cass. 31 déc. 1910;

20.- Intention criminelle – Constutation omise. — Lorsque l'intention criminelle nécessaire pour constituer une infraction n'a pas été relevée par le juge du fond et ne peut être déduite par la Cour de cassation des faits constatés dans le jugement, il y a lieu d'infirmer le jugement pour mauvaise application de la loi. (Cass. 1'' avril 1911 ;

21.--Intention criminelle - Déduction erronée des faits constatés. — Bien que l'existence de l'intention criminelle soit jugée souverainement en fait par le juge du fond, néanmoins la ('our de cassation peut contrôler la décision sur l'intention lorsque les faits retenus par le juge comme constants et constatés dans son jugement sont en opposition flagrante avec les déductions qu'il en a tirées au point de vue de l'intention ; la ('our de cassation restitue, dans ce cas, aux faits constatés leur véritable sens et redresse une application erronée de la loi. ( Cass. 3 juin 1911; N° 136, 1). -Jugement sur l'appel du Parquet omettant la mention de l'appel de l'accusé; v. Jugement en matière pénale, 117.

22.-Motifs du pourroi présentés par un frère ile l'accusé, — La déclaration d'un pourvoi en cassation avait été faite par l'accusé lui-même, mais les motifs du pourvoi avaient été présentés par son frère et aucune preuve n'avait été fournie pour établir que le frère avait reçu mandat à cette fin ;
Il fut jugé : que les motifs du pourvoi ne pouvaient être considérés comme émanant de l'accusé et que le pourvoi était, pour ce motif, irrecevable.

23.-Mullité de procédure à l'audience d'appel. — Une nullité de procédure, telle qu'une nullité concernant le serment d'un témoin, commise à l'audience d'appel avant les plaidoiries et à laquelle aucune objection n'a été faite, ne peut, plus tard, être invoquée devant la Cour de cassation.(Cass. 22 arril 1911; N" 78 ).

24.-Question de compétence. — Lorsque le tribunal sommaire s'est déclaré incompétent pour connaître d'une poursuite pénale pour le motif qu'il y a présomption de crime et que le tribunal d'appel a infirmé le jugement et renvoyé l'affaire devant le tribunal sommaire, on ne peut se pourvoir en cassation contre le jugement d'appel; une décision sur une question de compétence ne peut être contrôlée par la Cour de cassation que lorsque le jugement définitif sur le fond lui est déféré.(Cass.

25.-Idem. — La compétence d'un tribunal pénal est une question d'ordre public et une condamnation prononcée par un tribunal correctionnel sera infirmée par la Cour de cassation, sur la réquisition du Parquet, si les faits établis constituent un crime, alors même que c'était le Parquet qui avait déféré l'affaire au tribunal correctionnel. 6.- Délai d'appel - Jugement sur une demande en revendication dans une procédure d'erpropriation.- Dans une procédure d'expropriation la vente avait été suspendue en vertu de l'art. 597 C.P.C.C. sur une demande en revendication, mais le jugement de sursis avait été rendu à tort parce que le revendiquant n'avait pas fait le dépôt requis par le dit article. Le revendiquant fut débonté en 1'e instance et il interjeta appel de ce jugement. n fut jugé : que le délai d'appel contre le jugement rendu sur la demande en revendication était de dix jours en vertu de l'art. 600 C.P.A.C., puisque, la procédure ayant été en fait, quoiqu'à tort, suspendue, les motifs d'urgence justifiant ce délai d'appel existaient en l'espèce. 7.- Délai d'appel - Mort de la partie ayant obtenu gain de cause en 1"" instane. -- Une partie ayant obtenu gain de cause en 1'' instance mourut après avoir signifié le jugement et avant que le délai d'appel prévu à l'art. 353 ('.P.C.C. ne fût écoulé.

Appel fut interjeté contre ce jugement après l'expiration du délai susdit. L'appelant se prévalut de ce qu'il n'avait connu ni l'identité ni le domicile des héritiers de son adversaire décédé et il demanda que l'art. 358 ('.P.C.C., qui traite de la durée du délai d'appel en cas de décès de la partie condamnée en 1" instance, lui fût appliqué par analogie.

Il fut jugé: que le délai d'appel ne pouvait être calculé que conformément à l'art. 353 (.P.C.C. et que même si le délai d'appel pouvait être considéré comme devant courir de la date où l'appelant avait eu connaissance de l'identité et du domicile des héritiers, cela ne lui profiterait en rien, puisque plus de soixante jours s'étaient écoulés depuis cette date. (App. 11 avril 1911; N° 84).

But no greater right is thereby acquired against the owner of the neighbouring land, as for instance that he shall not erect buildings within one metre of the windows. Such owner may, indeed, build up to the edge of his land, although the windows are thereby blocked. (App. 8 Dec. 1910 ; No. 38, 1).

185.- Prescription-Sutferance.--The right to have windows overlooking the land of a neighbour at a distance of less than one metre from the boundary cannot be acquired by prescription if the windows were enjoyed by the sufferance of the neighbour.

The fact that the land of the neighbour had no building upon it and that the enjoyment of the windows did not cause him prejudice, will be considered in determining whether there is sufferance or not. (App. 8 Dec. 1910; No. 38, II).

186.- Prescription - Sutjerance - Light and air.- – The plaintiff claimed that he had acquired by prescription the right to keep open certain windows in the wall of his house erected on the boundary of his land, and claimed by virtue of that right to be entitled to demolition of a house erected by his neighbour on the boundary line and obstructing his windows. It was proved that during the prescriptive period the windows of the plaintiff looked over the roof of a room and then over land with no buildings on it, and that during that period the neighbour was not living there and could not, therefore, be said to have felt any diminution in the enjoyment of his property resulting from the existence of the windows ;

179.-Master and servant-Employer's liability-Injury through serrant's own negligence.--An employee cannot recover damages against his employer in respect of an injury sustained by him in the course of his employment, if the injury resulted from his gross negligence. (App. 19

180.- Master and servant-Employer's liability-Military service.-A soldier who is injured in the performance of his military duties cannot recover damages against the Government in respect of the injury, since he is in the same position in this respect as a soldier who is injured on the field of battle. (App. 19 Jan. 1911; No. 41, 11).

181.-Vexatious seizure-Damages.--A surety had, under an order of the President of the Court, effected conservatory seizure on the goods of the · debtor, and the order had been annulled by the Court and the seizure removed. The debtor, who was a shopkeeper, thereupon brought the present action against the surety claiming damages in respect of the seizure. It was proved in the action that the debtor's shops had been shut and his work stopped as a result of the seizure, that the debtor had, at the time of the seizure, already paid some of the debts guaranteed, that the other debts were at that time disputed, and that, moreover, the debtor's property was sufficient to enable him to pay the debts which were unpaid.

Held, (1) that the seizure had been effected without justification, that the debtor was, consequently, entitled to damages against the surety under art. 151 C.C., and that damages were due independently of whether the surety was in good or bad faith in effecting the seizure;
(2) That the damages should be fixed at the sum which the debtor would have earned if his work had not been stopped and not at a sum which would indemnify him for indirect loss. (App. 25
April 1911; No. 97).

Threats.

176.-Letter-Designation of person threatened.- The threats in writing mentioned in art. 284 P.C., as amended by Law No. 28 of 1910, are punishable under that article, although the person threatened has not been specifically mentioned, if he can be sufficiently identified from the facts of the case.

177.—Letter-Relation between addressee and person threatened. Although art. 284 P.C., as amended by Law No. 28 of 1910, does not provide that any relation should subsist between the person to whom a threat in writing is addressed and the person threatened therein, a relation must subsist between them, but it need only be such that the threat can make an impression on the mind. In particular, where a letter has been sent to the director of a company threatening violence to one of his subordinates, the relation required may subsist. (Cass. 17 Dec. 1910; No. 17).

178.-Defamation of an aggregate of persons—Right to damages of individuals comprising it. So far as defamatory words directed against an aggregate of persons, such as the Meglis of a Patriarchate, extend to the individuals comprising it, they are each of them entitled to damages in respect thereof. 148.-Suspension — Incupacity — Absence.- A person declared to be absent by a judgment of the Mehkemeh Sharieh is not subject to incapacity under Muhammedan Law, and consequently acquisitive prescription runs against him, notwithstanding art. 81 C.C. The fact that Muhammedan Law allows the suspension of the prescription of actions in cases of absence, minority or lunacy, is immaterial, since in all these cases the prescription is suspended on the ground of excuse and not of incapacity. (App.1st Dec. 1910; No.35).

149.—Uncultivated lands. The object of the provision of art. 57 C.C., that possession of uncultivated lands can only be taken with the authorization of the State, is only to prevent the ownership of such lands from being acquired by occupancy, and this article cannot be invoked to prevent the acquisition of ownership by prescription. 150.-Fruits of property wrongfully detained. It is the object of art. 211 C.C. to penalize the negliyence of the creditor and to prevent the debtor from being unduly impoverished. Claims for the fruits of property wrongfully detained fall within the application of these principles, and are, therefore, prescribed after five years. (App. :22
Dec. 1910; No. 50). -Suspension-Muhammedun Law; v. Prescription, Acquisitive, 148.

151.- Wakf property - Artion by nazir for delivery.- An action brought by the nazir of a wakf claiming delivery of land which he alleges belongs to the wakf, is admissible, notwithstanding the lapse of 33 years, being the period prescribed by Muhammedan Law for the prescription of actions in matters of wakf, if the defendant has admitted in the course of the action that the land belongs to the wakf, since actions are only prescribed under Muhammedan Law when the defendant denies the claim of the plaintiff. 128.- Constitution—Irregularity-Effect. -The Meglis Hasby performs duties of two distinct kinds, (1) duties which in France and similar countries are performed by the tribunals properly so called, and (2) duties which are performed in those countries by Family Councils. The judgments of the Native Court of Appeal deciding that the decisions of a Meglis Hasby which has not been constituted according to law are null for reasons of public policy, only refer to decisions of a Meglis Hasby when sitting as a veritable tribunal, that is to say to its decisions upon claims for interdiction or the removal of interdiction or the continuation of guardianship after the age of 18 years, and these judgments do not refer to deliberations of a Meglis Hasby when exercising the powers of a Family Council, such as when it grants or refuses to a tutor an authority to enter into an agreement concerning an immovable. In this latter case the deliberations of a Meglis Hasby whose constitution is irregular are not ipso facto void, and the Court has a complete discretion to determine their validity according to whether or not the irregularity is due to fraud or has caused prejudice to the person under disability.

Where, therefore, a Meglis Hasby which had authorized the guardian of a person under interdiction to purchase an immovable, had not been constituted in accordance with law by reason of the absence of a member of the family concerned as required by art. 4 of the Decree of the 19th MISTAKE

Held, that the action failed, since the irregular constitution of the Meglis was not in any way attributable to the vendors and was not itself the cause of direct or indirect loss to the person under interdiction. 114.-Administrative acts, Detention of lunatics.- An order for the detention in a Government lunatic asylum of a person who is insane and dangerous to the public safety is an administrative act, and the Native Tribunals are incompetent, under art. 15 of the Decree of Reorganization, to decide an action brought against the Government by a member of the lunatic's family claiming that the lunatic should be delivered up to him, or that he should be sent by the Government to a hospital abroad at the plaintiff's expense. (App. 1st Dec.

115.-Administrative acts-Mukallafa.—The mukallafas cannot be considered as registers kept for the private use of the Government; they are public registers, and it is of importance to the owners of land to have their names entered therein. The Native Tribunals are not, therefore, debarred by art. 15 of the Decree of Reorganization from ordering the Government, at the suit of the owners of land, to transfer the taklif into the plaintiff's name. (App. 28 May 1911;No.115).

116.- Alien guarantor.–Where a defendant claims to bring in as a party a guarantor who is a foreigner, the tribunal must consider whether the claim of guarantee is well-founded or primâ facie wellfounded, and, if it is not, refuse to admit it and try the action as between the original parties. If, on the other hand, the claim of guarantee is primâ facie well-founded, the tribunal must declare itself incompetent to try the action as regards both the guarantor and the original parties, for if it were to declare itself incompetent as regards the guarantor only, the defendant, being in that case obliged to enforce his guarantee by a separate action, would be in a worse position than if his guarantor were a native. (App. 30 May 1910;
No. 21). - Election petition-- Incapacity superrening after election ; v. Elections, 56.

117.—Marriage, Contract in consideration of.–Art. 16 of the Decree of Reorganization does not debar the Native Tribunals from hearing an action brought to enforce an agreement whereby the defendant, in consideration of the marriage of the plaintiff with his son, contracted to make to the plaintiff certain monthly payments. (App. 6 June 1911; No. 140). - Production of registers of a Meglis Hasby ; v. Procedure, Civil, 155.

118.- Wakf— Constitution, l'alidity.-A dispute as to whether the requisite formalities have been observed for the valid creation of a wakf is not “ a dispute relating to the constitution of a wakf” within the meaning of art. 16 of the Decree of Reorganization, and the Native Tribunals are competent to decide it. Thus a Native Tribunal, before which an action for delivery of land is brought by a nazir of a wakf, is competent to decide that no valid wakf of the land has been created, inasmuch as no hodget has been drawn up as required by the Regulations of A.H. 1283.

119.— Wakf— Constitution during last illness—Validity.-Notwithstanding the provisions of art. 16 of the Decree of Reorganization, the Native Tribunals are competent to decide that a wakf was constituted during the last illness of the constituent and, as such, is valid as to one-third only of his property. (App. 19 Jan. 1911; No. 55).

120.– Wakf-Nazir— Appointment and dismissal- The provision of art. 16 of the Decree of Reorganization of the Native Tribunals that those tribunals are incompetent to decide disputes relating to the constitution of a wakf, renders them incompetent to decide disputes as to the appointment and dismissal of the nazirs of wakfs. (Trib. Cairo,

The contention that the accused was in fact injured by the omission in so far as it indicated that the Court supposed him to acquiesce in the judgment in first instance, is sufficiently rebutted when it appears from the record of the sitting that the accused was heard in his argument against thatjudgment. 97.- Plea to jurisdiction sent by post.-The sending of conclusions by post is not a mode of procedure recognised by the law. The law requires the parties to appear in person or by mandatary (art.
70 C.C.C.Pr.) and provides for a judgment by default if either party fails to appear (arts. 119,

124 C.C.C.Pr.). If, therefore, the defendant has failed to appear, the fact that he has sent conclusions by post by which he objects to the competence of the Court on the ground of his place of domicile does not prevent a judgment by default from being validly given against him. But the Court cannot in such a case declare itself incompetent by its judgment by default, because a judgment by default is incompatible with the raising of pleas of any kind by the defaulting party ; by declaring itself incompetent, the Court is raising the plea of incompetence of its own motion in violation of the express provisions of art. 134 C.C.C.Pr., and in reliance upon the document sent by post to which the plaintiff is not legally bound to reply.

31.—“ Una via electa ” – Application of rule.- The rule of una via electa under art. 239 C.Cr.Pr., which provides that a person who has made a claim before a civil or commercial tribunal cannot, in respect of the same cause of action, set a penal tribunal in motion by appearing as civil claimant, bears a wider interpretation, by reason of the general terms of the article, than is given to that rule under the French law. .

Where a person had brought a civil action for the annulation of certain contracts inade between him and the defendant, on the ground that he was drunk when the contracts were made, and had subsequently instituted proceedings by direct summons against the other contracting party in respect of the forgery of the contracts;

Held, that the difference between the two actions was only apparent, that in fact the object, cause and parties were the same in both actions, and that the latter action was, consequently, inadmissible under art. 239 C.Cr.Pr. (Cass. 8

32.-Idem— Judgment on facts not raised.-A party to certain contracts made between him and another brought a civil action against the other contracting party claiming annulation of the contracts on the ground that he was drunk when the contracts were made,and subsequently instituted proceedings by direct summons against the defendant in the former action in respect of the forgery of the contracts.

The Summary Tribunal, by its judgment in the latter action, decided that the accused had not committed an offence which was punishable under the penal law, but had committed a fraud which was actionable civilly, and consequently acquitted the accused but granted damages to the civil claimant. On appeal by the accused against the decision as to damages, the Central Tribunal confirmed that decision. Thereupon the accused applied to the Court of Cassation to quash the judgment of the Central Tribunal.

Held, by the Court of Cassation, that the decision as to damages should be quashed, since the damages had not been granted in respect of facts relating to the alleged forgery, but in respect of a dispute which was not before the Court and which, in view of the former civil action, could not have been brought before it. (Cass. 8 April 1911; No. 90, II).

15. — Transfer – Irregular endorsement – Separate contract.— A bill of exchange may be transferred by a separate document, and a transfer so made has the effect of transferring the ownership of the debt. It follows that notwithstanding that the endorsement on a bill of exchange has not transferred the ownership of the debt for failure to mention that value has been received (arts. 134,

135 C. Com.), the endorsee is nevertheless owner of the debt, if it has been transferred to him by some other contract. Thus the endorsee is owner of the debt if it has, prior to the endorsement of the bill, been transferred to him, as a creditor of the endorser, by a contract made under the latter's composition with his creditors. 17.-Criminal intention- Judgment contradicted by facts found. Although the existence of criminal intention is decided finally by the Court trying the merits, yet the Court of Cassation can review the decision as to criminal intention, if the facts found by the Court and stated in its judgment are in direct contradiction with the deductions which it has drawn therefrom as to the intention of the accused ; in so doing the Court of Cassation is giving to the facts their true legal meaning and correcting a misapplication of law. (Cass. 3 June 1911; No. 136, 1).

18.- Criminal intention-Judgment unsupported by facts found.- Where the criminal intention necessary to constitute an offence has not been ascertained by the Court trying the merits and cannot be deduced by the Court of Cassation from the facts stated in the judgment, the judgment will be quashed for misapplication of law. (Cass. 1st April 1911; No. 89, 11).

19.- Error of law in grounds of judgment. The fact that there is an error of law in the grounds of a judgment of conviction is not a ground for quashing the conviction, if no misapplication of law has resulted therefrom in the operative part of the judgment. Where it has been wrongly stated in the grounds of a judgment that art. 1 of Law No. 5 of 1908 as to Habitual Offenders is not applicable, and by the operative part of the judgment the accused has been punished under the ordinary law, there is no misapplication of law in the operative part of the judgment, since it is within the discretion of the Court not to apply that article. (Cuss. 31 Dec. 1910 ; 10. 32). - Judgment on appeal by Parquet omitting to mention appeal by accused; y. Judgment, Criminal, 93.

7.- Time for appeal-Death of party in whose favour judgment given in first instance.-A party to an action who had been successful in first instance died after having served the judgment and before the time for appeal under art. 353 C.C.C.Pr. had expired. Appeal was brought after the expiration of that time. The appellant pleaded that he had not known of the identity and domicile of the heirs of his deceased opponent, and asked that art. 358 C.C.C.Pr., which deals with the time for appeal in the case of the death of the party who has failed in first instance, should be applied by analogy.
Held, that the time for appeal could not be calculated in any other manner than under art. 353

C.C.C.Pr., and that even if the time for appeal might be deemed to run from the date when the appellant knew of the identity and domicile of the heirs, this would not avail him, as more than sixty days had passed since that date. (Apr.
8. — Time for appeul- Judgments in arbitration matters.—The general provision of art. 353

C.C.C.Pr., as to the time for appeal, is applicable, in the absence of a special provision for the case, to a judgment given on opposition to the order for execution of an arbitration award under art. 727 ('.C.C.Pr. ( App. 15 Nor. 1910; 10. 23).

9.— Time for appeal- Judgment on a claim of rerindication in ea propriation proceedings.- In expropriation proceedings the sale of the property had been stayed under art. 597 C.C.C.Pr. pending the issue of a claim of revindication, but the order for stay had been wrongly made, inasmuch as the deposit required by that article had not been madde by the revindicant. The claim of revindication was dismissed in first instance and the revindicant appealed.

Held, that the time for appeal from the judgment on the claim of revindication was ten days under art. 600 C.C.C.Pr., on the ground that the proceedlings having in fact, although wrongly, been stayed, the considerations of urgency upon which that article was based were present in the case.
(“. Juge préparateur" Trib. App. Zayjaciy, 19 March 1911; No. 87).
